The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina calling fortnightly at Larnaca (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli, and Constantinople.
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.
Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai) Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden

div.head: AN INTERESTNG PHARAOH
div.p: The discovery if the tomb of Queen Thie has been one of the moet important events of recent date in Egyptological research and now the finding of the tomb of her bod is aroumng an equal amount of interest Mr. Arthor P. Weigall, Chief Inspector of the Department of Antiquities in Egypt, tells in "Blackwoods Magazine" the moving story of her son Akhna- ton, Hborn to the sound of music and to the clink of golden winuupe." He ascended the throne when still in his teen, and under the guidance of his mother began to break down old tradition especially those relating to the worship of Amon a deified mortal with many mortal limitations. Akhanatoas fint act was to proclaim Aton the only true God and himself his high priest. Then, as the worship of Amon and a hundred other deities confront- ed him everywhere, he abaodooed Thebes, and built a new capital elsewhere about 160 miles above Cairo. Though only fourteen, he vowed to shut himself up here with his god, devot- ing his life to his religion ; and this vow he kept throughout his brief life. His was Without doubt "the most enlightened religion which the world at that time had ever known, by no means pure and simple Run-worship :—

Akhnaton's god was the intangible and yet ever present Father of mankind, nuuie mani tent in sunshine. The youthful High Priest called upop his followers to search for their god not in the confusion of battle or behind the smoke of human ncrifioe^ but amidst the rtowers and treen, amiUt the wild duck and the fishes. He preached .an enlightened nature reotuiy : he wm perhaps the first apORtle of the Simple-Life.
Extracts from one of the hymns to Aton is quoted, and the remaikable similarity with Psalm civ. pointed out.

Meanwhile Akbnton devoted himself wholly And solely to hiA religion and to waging nome-what relentlem war agtjnst the old faith, and took no notice whatever of his generals in Aa Minor struggling to hold together the Egyptian Empire. "For twenty year、one metnoriaP to him pleaded uwe have been sending to oar Lord the King bat there has not come a word to ns, not not one. The oonsequence of Akhoaton s disregard of his empire was that there waft shortly do empire left; and when he did wake up to the deplor able fact, it wm too late. His dream of binding together the many countries ander his rule by giving them; single religion of love, truth, and peace wm never to be real ed・ When tribate suddenly oeMtd, and the few refogoM came staggering home to tell f the fill of the empire, Akhnaton Meow to I have received his death blow :一

He wm now not more than twenty five yeam of age; aod though hit portraits show that his face was already lined with euv and that bis body was thinner than it should bare been, be was a powertally-buiti man, having plenty of reserve strength. He was the father of several daughters, hut his queen had boroe him no son to aaooeed him ； and thu he mast have felt that his religion could not outlive him. With his empire lost with Thebes his enMny and with his tmsory weU-nifh empty, one fools that Akhnaton must have sank to the vory depths of despondency.

Hit very city fell into ruioa, and its temples and palaoM became the haunt ot jackals awl the home ofowh. In time he wm regarded a heretic, spoken of as "that criminal Mid bis name obliterated from his monument as it waa found in this year of grace 1907. Even hia own mother body wm not allowed to be iu the mme tomb with her too' and was therefore carried away—whtro is not quit known.

div.p: The Eastern Telegraph's repairing boat "Electra" returned to Port Said on Sunday night, having been out to sea 5 days repairing the cable not far from Alexandria.

div.head: Medical Licences.
div.p: On the proposal of the Director General of Public Health Department, HE. the Minister of the Interior has authorized Mr. Mahgoub Ahmed Sabitt, physician, and Mr. Michon Haim, pharmacist to practise in Egypt.

div.head: Discoveries of Rings.
div.p: A boy from the kindergarten of the Arme- nian National School at Boulac gothg home through the Sharia Bein-el-Surei has picked up three rings set with stones The owner can have the same by applying to the Director, M.K.G. Toarían at the school at Bonlac.

div.head: Government Accounts.
div.p: During September last the receipts of the EgyptianGovernment amounted to L.E.990,140, and the expenditure to L.E. 965,307, the total receipts during the first nine months of the year amounted to L E. 10,461,708 and the expenditure to L. E. 9,922 629 against L. E. 9,709,327 ami L E. 9,013,834 respectively for the corresponding period of last year.

div.head: Instruction at Mansourah.
div.p: Mansourah is a town that from an intellectual point of view will soon tie in the same rank as the biggest cities of Egypt. Amongst its leading men there are several who ask for the establishtndht of a Berlitz School there, and the general Director of this institution is now studying a project the execution of which would procure a real advantage to* the inhabitant* of Mansourah [Advt.]

div.head: Hashish Seizure.
div.p: Yesterday the Quay Police of Alexandria seized forty kilos of hashish, which were hidden in a boiler on quay 28. It is supposed that it was put there in order to be placed in the passenger train awaiting the arrival of the Austrian Lloyd steamer. The Coast Guard Administration have made two seizures of hashish during the past few days seizing 257 kilos 500 grammes at Port Said on the 24th inst. and 172 kilos in the Western Desert on the 27th inst.

div.head: Alexandria Swimming Club.
div.p: The championships which were competed for at Gabbary last Saturday resulted as follows : -100 yards Juniors.—(1) J. H Mitchinson, (2) D. A. Hamilton, (3) W. Keill : won by two yards, eight yards separating second and third ; R. F. Ecclestone, H. Elsworth, and II. Taylor also completed. 220yards Seniors. — Three members took part in thia important event, namely C. E. L. Randall, A. A. Ecclestone, and P. Psycha ; Randall won by three yards and Ecclestone came in second six yards ahead of Psycha. E. A.Darton (last year's winner) did not defend his title.

div.head: Khartoum Bridge Toll
div.p: We understand that it is the intention of the Sudan Government to institute a toll on foot ami vehicular traffic over the new bridge between Khartoum and Khartoum North when it is completed, it being hoped that in this manner revenue sntlicent for the payment of the interest on the money borrowed to build bridge, would lie accumulated The idea is an excellent one. There is of course a settled charge for each person who crosses the river by the existing ferry, and when one considers the enormous loss of time that will be saved by the use of the bridge, it is evident that to remove all tax would be absurd when the maintenance of a small charge would make the thing a paying concern while still greatly benefitting the public.

div.head: New Guide to Egypt.
div.p: Among the latest London publications announced is Murray's Handbook for Egypt ami the Sudan It has lieen revised, largely re written, and augmented hy H R. Hall, M.A., P.R.G.S., assistant in the Department of Egypitan and Assyrian Antiquities, British Museum. This (the 11th) edition has been thoroughly revised and brought up to date in all its departments. The whole work has been materially remodelled. Many sections have been arranged and re cast, as the Delta and Fayoum routes ; others have been greatly augmented, as Cairo ; and others have been almost entirely re written, as Thebes and the Oases. In addition, a new section has been specially written on the Anglo Egyptian Sudan. The maps and plans have been augmented, and have all been carefully revised. The English Arabic vocabulary (now printed separately), has been rearranged and expanded, and its usefulness for tourists has been increased by the addition of an outline of Arabic grammar.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Papayanni liner "City of Bombay" left Malta yestyday and is due here on the 1st prox. with passengers and mails.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S GREAT HONOUR.
div.p: Freedom of the City of London Presented.
Brilliant Gathering at the Guildhall.
Sir Joseph Dimsdale's Eulogy.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Monday Evening.

In the course of its historic past the Guild- hall of the City of Ixmdon has been the venue of many brilliant functions, and among these the great ceremony which has taken place there today of the conferment of the Freedom of the City upon Egypt's saviour, the Earl of Cromer, will rank as one of the most striking and interesting.

Lord Cromer's services to Egypt and the Empire have from time to time received an knowledgement from the King, these honours including the conferment of the Order of Merit, one of the most exclusive Orders in the gift of his Majesty, and earlier this year Parliament showed their appreciation by voting his lordship the sum of £50,000, the occasion being marked by a chorus of praise from both mem liers of the Government and thie Opposition.

All these manifestations, of the gratitude of King and nation must have deeply touched Lord Cromer, and done much to compensate him for the long years of haril and, at times, heart breaking work in Egypt, but today's presentation has been the crowning triumph of his life's-labours. London, the hub of the universe, has added his name to the dis-tinguished Roll of the noble and the brave whose deeds of glory and renown are writ large in the ages of history.

The scene in the great hall of the Guildhall to day was indeed grand and one to be long remembered. A large dias had been erected at the east end, and seated here, behind the Mace and the Sword of State, was the Lord Mayor, Sir William Purdie Treloar, arrayed in all the dignity of his high office, with the Ahlermen, in their scarlet robes, about him. Immeiliateh below were the chief officials of the City, and in front sat the members of the Court of Common Council in their blue maztyjno robes.
A Distinguised Gathering

The body of the hall and the galleries were filled with a distinguished gathering of peers, eminent statesmen, representatives of the Church, the Law and the Services, members of Parliament, and well known ladies and gentlemen. These included :—

The Archbishop of Canterbury, Lord Strath-conn. Viscount Errington, the Marquis and Marchioness of Bath. Lord Curton, Viscount Milner, the Earl and countess of Northbrook, Lord Revclstoke, Viscount ami Viscountess Goschen, Earl and Countess Granville, Lord Alcxamlcr Thynne, Viscomt and Viscountess Midleton, Sir Edward Grey, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Mr. John Morley, Secretary of State for India, Sir Vincent Caillard, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Baring, the Hon. Windham Baring, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Baring, Colonel Robert Baring, the Governor of the Bank of England, Sir Ernest and Miss Flower, Sir Colin Scott-Moncrieff, K.C.M.G., C.S.I., Lady Ruby Elliott, Sir Hugh and Ixuly Shaw Stewart, Sir Whittaker and Lady Ellis, Lady Faudell Phillipa, Sir Thomas ami Miss Crosby, Sir Edward and Ixuly Clarke, Rt. Hon. SirC. Hardinge, G.C M.G., the Hon. Sir Eric Barrington, K C.B., Sir Francis Campbell, K C.I.E, C.B., Sir Hamilton and Lady Lang, Sir Douglas Straight, Hon. Walter Rothschild, the Hon. Harry ami Mrs. Lawson, Mr. and Mrs. A. F. Walter, Mr. and Mrs. Moberly Bell, the Hon. Arthur Stanley, M.P„ Mr E. Dicey, Mr. William Archer, Mr. St. Leo Stracey, Mr. Carl Meyer, the Hon. Sidney Peel, Mr. and Mrs. W. H.'Pitman, and many others.
An Impressive Ceremony.

The ceremony itself was carried out with all the ancient and impressive ceremony, and little time was wasted in preliminaries. It should be explaiimd that the gathering was in essence a sitting of the Court of Common Council, so that when the Lord Mayor's procession haul passed to the dais, and the Lord Mayor had taken his sent, with the Earl of Cromer on his left in the place of honour, the Court was opened by the Town Clerk, Mr. J. Bell reading the items on the agenda. Of course, the only business to lie transacted was the ceremony which everyone was anticipating with pleasurable excitement. The Chief Clerk of the Chamberlain's Court, Mr. G. A. Pickering, read the quaint formula, by which the compurgators testified to the fitness of Lord Cromer to receive the Freedom of the City.
Afterwards the Master and Wardens of the Skinners Company formally presented Lord Cromer for the Freedom.
City Chamberlain's Oration.

The oration of the City Chamberlain, Sir Joseph Dimsdale, which followed, was an eloquent recital of the magnificent services which Lord Cromer has rendered to his country, and was punctuated throughout with enthusiastic applause.

The Chamberlain, the Rt. Hon. Sir Joseph Cockfield Dimedale, Bt, K C.V.O , has a long and distinguished record of services io the City to his credit. From 1891 to 1901 he held the position of Aiderman, and was a Sherifl in 1894. He represented the City on the L.C.C. for five years, 1895 1900, and satin Parliament as one of the City's representatives from 1900 to 1906. He was paid the signal compliment of being elected Lord Mayor during the

memorable year 1902, and carried the Crystal Sceptre in front of his Majesty at his Coronation. He was created a Knight in 1894, and Baronet in 1902, and in the latter year also he was elected a member of the Privy Council, and was made a Knight Commander of the Victorian Order. He has held the position of City Chamberlain since 1902. He is a Past Master of the Grocers Company ; Past Grand Warden and Past Grand Treasurer of Freemasons of England.

Sir Joseph, in the course of his speech said : Among the many privileges enjoyed by citizens of London, none are more highly trea surod than the presentation of honorary freedom. We are thereby enabled to set the impress of the imperial city and the Empire upon the actions and lofty aims of those who have signalised themselves by their devotion to the welfare of their country. We meet today to acclaim one of the greatest living personalities of our time and it is with peculiar pleasure that we greet Lords Cromer within the walls of the ancient Guildhall. The last years of his life bo ungrudgingly placed at the disposal of his country and his Sovereign in evory capacity. He has left his mark and a lasting, solid gold behind him.
Lord Cromer's Services.

Sir Joseph Dimsdale then reviewed Lord Cromer's 25 years' magnificent services in Egypt He hatl produced, out of chaos, prosperity, hope, peace, and good government, and all this whs owing, under the divine blessing, to the courage and determination of one man. While these great events have been (tassing in Egypt there have been different Governments at Home and different Premiers at Downing Street. Such was Lord Cromer's personality and so patently just and sincere his policy, tliat Mr Gladstone, Lord Salisbury, Lord Roseberry, Mr. Balfour, and Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman, one and all, had accorded him their co operation and support in his great and noble work.

Sir Joseph Dimsdale then quoted Sir Edward Grey's speech in the House of Commons on the occasion of Lord Cromer's retirement.and in conclusion lie said that whatever should the thp future history of Egypt Lord Cromer's name would lie indelibly engraved upon her annals as her regenerator, financier, statesman, administrator—the great Pharaoh of Modern Egypt.

At the close of his speech the Chamberlain ofiereil the right hand of Fellowship to Lord Cromer, welcoming him as a Freeman of the City, and presented to him the gold casket containing the Franchise Ticket in the name of the Lord Mayor and the Corporation
Lord Cromor's Speech.
On rising to respond, the Earl of Cromer fiad a great ovation, and was visibly affected by the warmness of the greeting.

Lord Cromer, in an excellent speech which i lasted half an hour, thanked the City moat cordially for considering him worthy to he inscribed on the roll containing so many illustrious names. He could have done little in Egypt but tor the occurrence of adventitious circumstances, the chief of which wax the fact that of late years foreign affairs had been elevated to a great extent out of the somewhat heated atmosphere of pat ty strife. He thanked Sir Edward Grey for his support in circumstances of no common difficulty.

Having paid warm tribute to his coadjutors, one of the most able of whom was Sir Eldon Gorst who had succeeded him, Lord Cremer said that Sir Eldon Gorst would 2 achieve success, particularly if be did not allow himself to be hurried by faddists in England and the numerous scribes who looked upon London as a sort of political Mecca.
Enemies to Progress.

Referring to Nationalism, Lord Cromer said that it would be a mistake to take too seriously the Nationalists or their friends in England. Some of the latter misled the Egyptians as to the true trend of public opinion at home and encouraged the hope that political development in Egypt could be much more rapid than was possible. These he regarded as the worst enemies to Egyptian progress. Extremists in caim would not be conciliated save on terms which would involve a relapse to all the misgovernment and disorder of the past. He saw but one method of dealing with the unrest in Egypt and India It was to continue stead fastly to do-our duty towards the people of those countries, and to come down with a heavy hand upon the extremists who overstepped the limits of the law, but at the same time not to be deterred from adopting such reforms as would satisfy the aspirations of all moderate and reasonable men.
The Country's Prosperity.

Alluding to the financial crisis he said that the prosperity of the country 1n no way suffered and he hoped it would do something to stop the over-speculation which had been such a mischievous feature of the Egyptian markets in Ute years. Future prosperity was assured owing to the work of the hydraulic engineers, thevtrue makers of Modern Egypt, who had

secured the country from drought and assured the cotton crop. Lord Cromer then explained the habit and custom of hoarding gold and said that he hoped the creation of saving banks and the increased circulation of paper money and increasing banking facilities might improve matters, but it would be a slow process.

At the conclusion of Lord Cromer's reply, the Lord Mayor introduced to him the mover and seconder of the resolution conferring the Freedom upon his lonlship, Mr. J. W. Domo-ney, and Sir George Fandell Philips, G.C.I.E. Bt., and the Sherifls, Aiderman Burnett, and Mr. C. C. Wakefield.
After the ceremony at the Guildball the Lord Mayor entertained the Earl of Cromer lo luncheon at the Mansion House, at which a distinguished gathering was present.
The Golden Casket.

The casket in which the Freedom of the City was presented to Lord Cromer is of 18ct. gold, and is specially designed with a harmonious blending of English and Egyptian ornament as being eminently appropriate to the recipient's great work in Egypt; the upper and lower mouldings are embossed with a lotus ornament, and the box is divided into panels by pilasters of Egyptian design

The central position is occupied by the full anus of Lord Cromer, in heraldic blazon, ami on either side are janels with Egyptian soldiers, against a hackgrotind of blue enamel. Further panels contain coloured enamel views, one being of modern Cairo am! the other of the Pyramids. There are similar panels on the reverse bearing views of London, the centre l»eing engraved with the following inscription :--
PRESENTED
By The Corporation Of The City Of London
With The Freedom Of The City
To The
Rt.Hoy.Evelyn Baring,EARL OF CROMER,
G.C.B., O.M., G.C.M G.,K.C.8.I.,C.1.B., LLD.,
IN RECOONITION OF HIS LONG AND EMINENT PUBLIC
SERVICES.
GUILDHALL, OCTOBER 28TH, 1907.

The lid of the box is exceptionally distinctive. The bold dome, which is chased with lotus ornament, is surmounted by a finely modelled figure of Britannia, significant of British influence in Egypt under Lord Cromer's wise and beneficent guidaime. At each angle of the lid are representations of the minarets of the Cairo MtKsque, and under a cornice of harmonious style appears the recipient's initial surmounted by a coronet.

A silver gilt base, with four fine models of the Sphinx, and at each end an Egyptian obelisk with hieroglyphicx, supports the box. The curve of the base is utilized to display Lord Cromer's onlers and decorations, the remainder being ornamented with suitable emblems. The full blazon of the City Arms appears in the centre of the obverse, and the whole casket rests upon an oak plinth.

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS.
div.p: HOW MANY PARTIES ARE THERE?

The native mind appears to lie grievously troubled owing to the multiplication of political parties in Egypt and the favourite occupation of the melbbers of the various groups now consists in sending lengthy contributions to their favourite newspapers to prove that their party is the only genuine representative of public opinion and that all other Nationalist, who refuse to join their clique, are unprincipled, self seeking humbugs, who are not inspired by any genuine feelings of patriotism, but on the contrary by the most sordid sentiments.

The "Manchester Guardian," which has been the journal favoured by Mr. Wilfrid Blunt for his letters on Egyptian affairs, has been considered by Egyptians to have rather favoured the cause of Nationalism owing to its strong Radical proclivities. But recently the "Manchester Guardian" announced that theie were three parties in Egypt and this announcement has caused great vexation to Kamel's followers, who consider that the Moderate Nationalists, represented by "Al Moayad" of Sheikh Aly Youssef, and "Al Minbar," of Hafiz Awad, the "Party nf the Nation, of "Al Guerida,'' and the Egyptian Li era Party are all of no account. El Sayed Hassan Moussa el Akad I in a oontribution to "Al tawa,'' declares that the statement of the "Manchester Guardian" is not true as Kamel's party embraces all true Nationalists, as was proved by the meeting at the Zizinia Theatre. He states that the "Party of the Nation " , only consists of supporters of "Al Guerida."

Meanwhile the organ of the "Party of the I Nation" has described the Egyptian Liberal I as an imaginary party, which has elicited a manifesto from Mohamed Bey Wahid the leader of the Liberals, who replies to thia insinuation at some length.

div.head: THE Hotel Casino San Stefano
div.p: Will be open during Winter

div.head: THE BRITISH OCCUPATION OF EGYPT.
div.p: MR. BLUNT'S CHARACTER.
"Once a twenty years resident in Egypt" sends the following letter to "The Times".

Twenty-five years ago I was your Correspondent in Egypt. In that capacity I frequently disagreed with the policy pursued by Sir Edward Malet, and my criticisms of that policy in your columns and elsewhere caused an interruption in our friendly relations, though not, I am glad to believe, in our mutual esteem. I merely recall this fact to show that I am not a prejudiced supporter of Sir Edward, whom I have hardly seen since he left Egypt.

One of the chief subjects of my disagreement with him was that be persisted in tak ing Mr. Wilfrid Blunt too seriously, thereby apparently inducing Mr. Gladstone to treat him as an authority, until at last Mr. Gladstone and Mr. Blunt between them made the British occupation inevitable.

To me, and to most people resident in Egypt at the time, Mr. Blant was a specimen of that type of British tourist who, with no evil intentions, but suffering from acute me. galomania, thinks that he can acquire the reputation of an authority by spending a few weeks in a country, by meddling in its politics-of which he has not a rudimentary knowledge - and by writing letters thereon to newspapers.

A year or two before Mr. Blunt came to Egypt I had met a young man who, after six weeks in the country, announced to me his intention of writing an Arabic grammar because he found the language so simple. Mr. Blunt confined himself to no such harmless experiment, but devoted himself to what he called the study of the people. He was known in Cairo as "the mad Englishman" who would greedily swallow anything, and it was for a time & favourite amusement with certain people to induce an intelligent donkey boy to pose as a leading native and to pour horrible legends into his sympathetic ears. For a time I believe that even Sabunji himself favoured this deception, for his own powers of imagination, though great, were exhausted. It was, however, playing with edged tools ; for, though Arabi, who was a muddle headed but honest fellah, took no advantage of his ignorance, there were others of the party, more intelligent and less scrupulous, who were willing to use him as their tool and to laugh at him behind his back : while our own and other Consulates never much in touch with the native element were easily imposed upon.

The origin of Mr. Blunt's megalomania and self imposed mission was always popularly ascribed to the fact that he had married a connexion of Lord Byron. Byron was a poet--Mr. Blunt wrote poetry. Byron espoused the cause of Greek liberty, and Mr. Blunt espoused the cause of what be called Egyptian liberty. The parallel was incompleto, for Byron died at Missolonghi and Mr. Blunt lives at Crabbet Park.

But his attempts in prose and in verse to represent himself as the angel who rode in the whirlwind and directed the storm are farcical in the eyes of any one who knows anything of the circumstances. In one sense only is it true. Mr. Blunt was, with Mr. Gladstone, the chief provocative cause of the British occupation of Egypt, as was George III. of the independence of the United States -- they raised the whirlwind and were shattered by it.

As for Sir Edward Malet, I have said that I disagreed with his policy. I have written severe things about it, nor do I know that with regard to that policy itself I have any. thing to retract ; but, looking back over a quarter of a century, I think I did not perhaps make sufficient allowance for the difficulties of any man serving under the Government of that period. I was younger ; I had not then thoroughly realized with what little intelligence the world is governed, and, believing that Cabinets were always ruled by intelligence, I perhaps attributed to him the follies of those whose instructions he was bound to obey.

But in my greenest youth I should never have been guilty of classing together Sir Ed. ward Malet and the man who openly avows that he sent to "The Times" a statement for which of course we had not a shadow of authority to go upon" (p. 433).

div.head: SIR WILLIAM GARSTIN.
div.p: The Cairo correspondent of the "Times," in announcing Sir William Garstin's new appointment, remarks that it is regarded as of great importance, as he is the first British representative on the board who has combined the highest technical experience and knowledge with great administrative ability, It may be confidently predicted that his influence will be exerted, whenever possible, on behalf of British shipping interests and those of the Egyptian Government, into whose hands the canal will eventually pass.

It is hoped that it may be possible for him to remain in the service of the Government till April, and that he may thus be enabled to pay a final visit to the White Nile and completo certain important works connected with Egyptian irrigation. It is hoped also that in the exercise of his new duties he will frequently visit Egypt, where the greatest value is attached to his advice.

Sir William Garstin's successor will in all probability be Mr. Webb, an administrator of proved ability and fearlessness, who commands the confidence and respect of the Government, the people, and the present chief.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: Within the last three days we have received two letters containing reflections on the behaviour of officers of the Army of Occupation at Alexandria. Both these letters are anonymous and cannot therefore be published. Even if the signatures of the writers had been appended, they would not have been published, not because, as one of these correspondents insinuates, we are an English newspaper, but because we have good reason to believe that in the two cases of misconduct, which form the subject of these complaints the offenders were civilians. It appears to be an amiable delusion among some of the foreign inhabitants of this city that every Englishman, who dons a dress suit in the evening, is prima facie a member of the Army of Occupation.

div.head: CAIRO'S OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: It is said that the question of a new opera house for Cairo has been settled at last, but that the new building - will not be commenced until the year after next. The original plans offered by Mr. More, have, we are informed, been rejected, though why, we are at present at a loss to understand. He offered to build a new opera house on a site to be chosen by the Government, for the sum of LE. 200,000, provided that he should be given the right to build houses or stores on the site of the existing opera house, each buildings to revert after a lapse of years to the Government.

The scheme which it is reported has been adopted is that of Mr. Sachs, a London theatre builder, who is to build an exact model of the Covent Garden theatre in the Esbekieh Gardens for the sum of L.E. 300,000 to be paid by the Government, and it is also said that the street opposite the Grand Continental Hotel, and the Splendid Bar (Sharia Kamel) is to be increased in width by encroaching upon the gardens to some extent.

We have received no official confirmation of the above statements, and at first sight it would appear to be almost incredible that the Government should refuse such an advantageous offer as that of Mr. More appears to be, and close with one which entails an extra expenditure of L.E. 100,000.

Cairo needs a new opera house, and needs it badly, but over a quarter of a million is a lot of money and we doubt if the expenditure of so large a sum can be entirely justified when one considers how very short is the opera season in Cairo. However criticism on this point must wait until official details of the proceedings are given to the public.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi)

L'aspect de la corbeille était ce matin celui d'une séance d'été. Peu de monde, la plupart occupés à tont autre chose qu'à des transactions. En tous cas, celles-ci ont été absolument Dulles; 25 par ci par là et encore dans la catégorie des petites valeurs, United Lands, Ritz Hotels et Delta Land. Les valeurs dirigeantes et en général toutes celles dépassant un certain prix ont été complètement négligées. Cela ne veut pas dire que les offres aient été nombreuses mais simplement que les vendeurs se trouvant presque seuls dans la corbeille n'ont pas jugé à propos de casser les cours sans résultat ; en quoi d'ailleurs ils ont agi fort sagement.

Malgré cela, toutefois, il s'est produit une certaine dépression sur une partie de la cote, provenant sans doute de quelques détenteurs désireux de réaliser, mais encore une fois, la plupart de leur offres sont restées sans contrepartie.

L'Agricole revient de 8 3/32 à 8 1/16. LA National Bank perd 3/16 à 21 3/8. On offre la Delta Light à 10 1/8. Les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie fléchissent de 138 à 135, la Daïra de 13 1/2 à 13 3/8 et la Béhém de 23 à 223/4. En revanche, à la suite d'une demande assez suivie, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier progresse de 297 1/2 à 298 acheteurs l'ancienne et de 254 à 255 la nouvelle, ainsi qne l'Union Foncière de 4 3/4 8 4 13/16.

La Banque d'Athènes rétrograde de 108 1/2 à 108. Les Nungovich Hotels, perdant graduellement l'énorme avance qu'ils avaient récemment gagnée, clôturent à 17, en nouvelle baisse de 1/4 de livre. Pour la Land Bank les acheteurs ont également disparu : le cours retombe de 7 3/16 à 7 1/16. Le Crédit Franco-Egyptien recule aussi de 4 3/16 à 4 1 8.

Dans la catégorie des titres secondaires, nous voyons la Salt & Soda reculer pareillement de 17/9 à 17/3, l'ordinary Khedivial Mail de 22/9 à 22/6, la Building Lands de 2 à 1 15/16 et la fondateur United de 1 à 7/8; l'action United est, au contraire, soutenue à 9/32 acheteurs. La fondateur Levico, qu'on avait cessé de coter depuis quelques jours, s'inscrit à 3 livres.

Le Comptoir Financier et Commercial (Campos), après avoir retenu toute l'attention de notre marché la semaine dernière, retombe dans le marasme juste à la veille de l'assemblée générale qui doit avoir lieu le 31 de ce mois. Le prix fléchit encore de 2 29 32 l'ancienne et 2 31/32 la nouvelle à 2 27/32 et 2 29/32 respectivement. La part de foudateur réactionne également de 2 1/16 & 2. De rares échanges ont eu lien ; dans le nombre il faut compter 25 actions anciennes vendues aux enchères publiques au cours de 2 7/8.

Jusqu'ici la corbeille comptait une bonne partie d'optimistes. Mais aujourd'hui l'inaction et la baisse ont refroidi beaucoup d'enthousiasmes. On est en tous cas unanime à reconnaitre que les affaires ne vont pas. Quant aux motifs, ont met surtout en avant la crise américaine ; nous avons déjà dit hier ce qu'il fallait en penser.

Nous n'avons pas besoin d'ajouter que la tendance est mauvaise, ce qui ne veut pas dire que demain il y aura encore baisse mais simplement que pour le moment l'ensemble du marché tend vers une nouvelle dépression.

D'autres plus judicieux nous annoncent chaque jour que notre cote va reprendre le lendemain ! On voit la confiance qu'il faut mettre dans les paragraphes frémissants de ces haussiers à outrance (lisez vendeurs).

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Lundi 28 Octobre.
Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est renseigné en hausse de 1/8 à 4 7/8 pour cent.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé hier de 1/4 à 82 3/4. L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 102 1/2. La National Bank a haussé de 1/8 à 21 7/8. La Daïra a été ferme à 133/4, de même que l'Agricole et la Delta bright à 8 14 et 10 1/4 respectivement. I
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien qui vendredi avait gagné 3 francs, a perdu samedi 5 francs à 690. La Banque d'Athènes a été soutenue à 110 et les Lots Turcs à 167.

Ici, les causes de la récente dépression n'ayant pas encore cessé et les banques continuant à mettre leurs clients en demeure d'avoir à liquider leurs dossiers, les offres sur le marché sont toujours très abondantes. Bien qu'il se fasse des achats très suivis sur certaines valeurs les cours rétrogradent avec une ténacité que des liquidations continues peuvent seules expliquer.

De fait, la panique de New-York a peut être pu décourager quelques acheteurs, mais n'a certainement pas engagé de spéculateurs à vendre, notre marché n'ayant rien de commun avec l'Amérique et ne pouvant être touché par ce qui se passe là-bas que très indirectement, soit par le hausse du taux de l'escompte résultant de la solidarité financière de tous les pays.

Les causes de la baisse sont donc unique inent égyptiennes et par cela même ne sauraient durer, car, somme toute, le travail de déblaiement qui se fait actuellement ne peut qu'être très salutaire, assainissant la situation de la place et éloignant le cauchemar de nouvelles liquidations lorsque la saison des affaires battra son plein. C'est pourquoi le pessimisme actuel est exagéré ; nous reverrons la hausse comme nous verrons aussi des réactions : C'est dans l'ordre des choses et la reprise n'en sera que plus rapide.
Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National Bank est plus faible 1 21 7/16-1/2 malgré sa reprise de vendredi et samedi à Londres L'Agricole se comporte mieux à 8 1/16-1/8. La

sont très actives, l'ancienne en tassement à 296 et la nouvelle en progrès à 258-254. L'obligation Béhéra retombe à 4 1/4 et les fondateurs Allotments à P.T. 55-56. L'Enterprise and Development est lourde à 8 1/4-3/8. L'American Nile se relève légèrement à 2 7/16-1/2. Les Frigorifiques progressent à 2 1/4-5/16.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich rétrogradent à 163/4-17 et les Egyptian Hotels (Baehler) à 5 15/16. La fondatear National Hotels s'affaisse à P.T. 25.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land retrouve sa faveur d'antan à 1 5/16 en gain de 1/16. Les Markets haussent à 26/3. La New Egyptian recule à 12 - L'Aboukir est également en baisse à 27/6. Les Cotton Mills cotent 1/6. LA Nile Cold Storage est en progrès * 05/16. L'Ordinary Khedivial Mail réagit à 22/6. Les Oasis (Western Egypt) sont mieux disposées à 0 3/8-7/16.
Nous recevons d'un de nos lecteurs les réflexions ci-après que nous reproduisons comme typiques en l'état actuel des affaires.

"On s'étonne parmi les non initiés de la baisse persistante qui affecte justement les seules valenrs favorisées du public et qui aient, par l'état prospère de leurs affaires, un marché suivi. On me dit, et je n'ose en douter vu l'honorabilité indiscutable de mon informateur, qu'il y aurait là le résultat de la façon d'agir de certains établissements de crédit. Un d'eux même aurait obligé, on ne sait pour quelle cause, an de ses clients à se défaire, quoiqu'il en et d'autres, de titres susceptibles de revenir très prochainement à des cours plus élevés, alors que l'infortuné aurait de beaucoup préféré se débarrasser de papiers cotés nomidalement à des cours visiblement supérieurs à ce qu'on en pourrait tirer.

"Il faut espérer que ces établissements reviendront à une appréciation plus exacte de la réalité et, bien que je n'aie pas la sottise de vouloir apprendre à nager à des poissons, me fiant au bon sens de leur directeur, j'aime à croire qu'ils comprendront comme ce mode de faire est contraire à leurs propres intérêts et bon tout au plus à nnire an relèvement du marché tout entier." Les recettes de la "Delta Light Railways" pour la semaine au 19 Octobre 1907 se sont élevées à L.E. 5,710 contre L.E. 6,235 en 1906, soit en diminution de L.E. 525. Les recettes totales à partir du ler Avril se chiffrent par L.E. 137,419 contre L.E. 120,975 durant l'exercice précédent, soit en plus-value de L.E. 16,444.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

MM. les actionnaires de la "Société Anonyme des Immeubles d'Egypte" sont informés que le dernier versement de Lst. 2 par action de la nonvelle émission doit être effectué à la National Bank, à Alexandrie, le 31 Octobre courant, contre présentation des certificats provisoires au porteur.

div.head: Cloture de la Bourse Khediviale

div.head:
PRINCE VON BUELOW.
KAISER'S VISIT TO LONDON.
NO POLITICAL IMPORTANCE.

div.p: It is semi-officially announced that although Prince von Buelow would welcome the opportunity of responding to the friendly sentiments expressed in serious political circles in Great Britain and of personally testifying that he had never been an opponent of England, he is unable to accompany 'the Emperor as, apart from pressure of work incidental to the opening of the Reichstag, his accompanying His Majesty would be used to attach to the visit a political importance which it does not possess. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE HARDEN EXPOSURES.
FRANCE AND GERMANY.

div.p: Herr Harden alleged that the camarilla induced the Emperor to believe that reconciliation with France was possible. His Majesty's resentment at the diplomatic rebuff precipitated the Morocco crisis, and when the exposure came the Emperor was the first to step in and break up the camarilla. (Renter)

Lord Cromer has been presented with the freedom of the city at the Guidhall. His Lordship was heartily cheered. Returning thanks Lord Cromer emphasized that during recent years foreign affairs had happily been removed from the atmosphere of party politics. He was sure that Sir Eldon Gorst would achieve success if he did not allow himself to be hurried by Eng. lish faddists and the numerous scribes in Egypt who regarded London as a political Mecca. He warmly acknowledged Sir E. Grey's loyal support and referred to the Anglo-Russian agreement, which he considered was perfectly justifiable in spite of certain concessions. It was a mistake to treat the Egyptian Nationalists and their friends too seriously. He was not alluding to those who desired a reasonable extension of self-governing institutions, but the extremists who existed in Cairo, Calcutta, and Dublin. He saw only one method of dealing with the Indian and Egypt unrest and that was to continue steadily doing our duty, to descend with a heavy hand on the agitators who over stepped the law, and to adopt gradually the reforms required by moderate men. (Reuter)

The Spanish Sovereigns arrived this morning and dined at the Palais de l'Elysée. Replying to M. Fallières King Alfonso said that new bonds limited France and Spain for the general work of peace. The Sovereigns left this evening for Cherbourg on their way to England. (Havas)
Two hundred and sixty results of the Duma elections are known. They include 127 members of the Right, 83 Octobrists, 17 Cadets, and 26 members of the left. (Haras)
A state of siege has been proclaimed.(Havas)

div.head:
THE AMERICAN CRISIS.
GOLD SHIPMENTS FROM EUROPE.
THE PRESIDENT'S CONGRATULATIONS.

div.p: 6,500,000 dollars of gold have been engaged for shipment from Europe. President Roosevelt has written congratulating Mr. Cortelyou and the financiers on the manner with which they handled the crisis which threatened the destruction of credit essential to legitimate business. (Reuter)

div.head:
TERRIBLE WEATHER IN ITALY.
OVERFLOW OF THE PO.
NAPLES INVADED BY SEA.

div.p: The Po has overflowed and flooded the environs of Piacenza. The railway line from Piacenza to Alessandria is interrupted. The inhabitants of the lower part of Piacenza have taken refuge on the roofs from where they have been rescued by the troops. 500 people are homeless. (Reuter)
A storm has occurred here. Many palaces have been flooded. The roof of a factory has been carried off. A part of the town has been invaded by the sea.
Queen Margherita has given 20,000 francs for the relief of the Calabrians. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE ITALIAN EARTHQUAKES.
GREAT BRITAIN OFFERS WARSHIP.

div.p: Admiral Drury has offered the Italian Government to send a warship to Gerace to render help to the earthquake victims. The offer has been declined owing to bad anchorage and the distance inland of the most stricken districts. (Reuter)

div.head:
LADY PASSENGER INCIDENT.
THE OFFICIAL VERSION
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT.).
Port Said, Saturday.

"The Port Said incident," which is generally accepted as descriptive of the misfortunes which befel a certain lady passenger to this port at the hands of a dragoman, bas, owing to the prominence afforded it in your columns, become almost the sole topic of conversation here. Happily the affair, though sufficiently serious, has been proved to have been considerably exaggerated. My report of the case was based upon the report of one who proved to be an unreliable on-looker, but equally exaggerated reports have also been published in our two local papers. This evening, however, I have been granted an interview with a police official, who gave me the following details :-

An Australian lady passenger from the S.S. "Oroya" on coming ashore was accosted by a crowd of guides One of these was engaged by the lady to show her the interesting places of our town. During the afternoon the guide took the lady into a shop for refreshments, which, it is supposed, contained some sort of drug. The reason for supposing the drink contained drugs is that the lady was in a dazed condition when interviewed by the police. In the same shop the lady was also shown some indecent post-cards. The lady, being disgusted at what she had seen, requested the guide to take her to the ship immediately. After leaving the shop, and when nearing the Savoy Hotel, a police officer who was passing overheard the lady say she wished to be taken on board, and the guide trying to persuade her to accompany him to his house first. Here the police officer interfered, and, from a statement made by the passenger, the guide was arrested and taken to the Caracol, where it appears he threatened to strike the officer in charge. The passenger was taken on board and again repeated her statement, bat in a very dazed manner.

This morning the guide appeared at the Native Court to answer the charges (1) Of proposing to a lady passenger to accompany him to his house (presumably for indecent purposes) (2) Of threatening to strike a police officer. The court acquitted the prisoner on both charges, and allowed him to continue his profession. The Commandant of Police gave notice of appeal against the decision re the second charge. The first charge will have to be dropped, as the case is none too clear, according to the laws of the Native Court.

The case, however, though evidently exaggerated, is a sufficient illustration of the low character of our "official dragomans," who are a disgrace to the town and never ought to be allowed to trade with respectable persons. It is more than remarkable that our Commandant of Police has no voice in the selection of these "official dragomans," it seems to me that he is the one and only official of the Government to whom should be given the right of awarding and cancelling dragomans' certificates.

div.head: German Minister's Visit.
div.p: Mr. Dernburg, the German Secretary for the Colonies, and party, arrived at Suez from German East Africa yesterday evening, and left immediately for Cairo by special train. After spending a few hours in the capital the party took train for Port Said where they arrived soon after 11.30 p.m. Mr. Dernburg was met at the station by Mr. Bronn, German Consul at Port Said. The party drove direct to the quay where they re-embarked on board the S.S. "Prinz Regent." The vessel proceeded immediately afterwards.

div.head: The New City Liner.
div.p: The S.S. "City of Paris", under the command of Capt. Campbell, arrived here to-night on her maiden voyage from Liverpool and Naples with passengers and general cargo for Calcutta. The "City of Paris" is the largest of the Eller man lines fleet, and with the exception of a few mail steamers, she is the largest vessel running to India. She is 509 feet in length, 57 ft 9 inches in breadth, 36 ft 67 inches in depth, of about 9,000 tons gross, and has a single screw, quadruple-expansion engines by Messrs. Barclay, Curie & Co., capable of giving a service speed of fifteen knots. The following passengers disembarked here for Egypt and the Sudan :-

Mrs. Graham Charlton, Mrs. Flower and family, Miss N. Macdonald, Miss Nicoll, Mr. Ferguson Lee, Mrs. C. Crawtord, Mr. and Mrs. Walker, Mrs. Smith, Mrs. Cheetham, Mrs. Stopford, Mrs. A. E. Frampton Jones, Mr. W. Clements and Miss W. Watson.

div.head: Warships Visite.
div.p: The first class cruiser "Europa" arrived at Port Said from Suez on Thursday evening with time expired crew from H.M.S. "Powerful. The "Europa" coaled and proceeded to Malta on Friday night. H M.S. "Edgar" also arrived here Thursday night from China and proceeded to Malta this morning.

div.head: Cricket Match.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon a cricket match was played between the ship and shore teams. After a very exciting game Port Said won, but only by two runs, the soore being Port Said I. S. Club 49 and H.M.S. "Edgar" 47.

div.head: HUMDAN DISTRICT QUIET.
div.p: ADEN, October 23.

The trouble in the Turkish district Humdan is practically at an end, now that Ramadan has commenced. Many villages in Hamdan, have been destroyed by the Turks. The inhabitants of Humdan are in league with the Imam, and have recently given much trouble to the Turks. Negotiations are now being made by the Turks with the chiefs of Humdan for the recovery of the Turkish arms recently captured by the people.

div.head: German Enterprise.
div.p: Reports received from the Red Sea go to show that Germany is directing her attention afresh to Farsan, the most important island in the Red Sea. According to these reports a German ship recently called there and landed several men, dressed in Turkish costume, on Sayir, the headland of Farsan, in order to again explore the island. The Germans who arrived on board the ship made purchases of some provisions at very high prices and distributed some presents among the people of the island. It is said that the latter have been attracted by their gold and courteous conduct, and that they have given them a paper signifying their willingness to live under German rule, if the Sultan cedes the island to them.

If these reports are correct, the interest betrayed by Germany, in farsan is very peculiar, when considered with the latter's previous attempt to force a coal depot there. It may be remembered that Germany, some years ago, landed coal at Parsan without the permission of the Sultan and despite the protests of the local Turkish authorities, and made an exploration of the Island, in consequence of which friction arose between Germany and the Sultan, the latter strongly resenting the German intrusion. The dispute was, at length, settled, and in view of Germany's declaration, that she only wanted a coal depot in the Red Sea "during the Chinese crisis," the Sultan agreed to allow Germany to store coal in an island in the Red Sea of his own selection, subject to the stipulation that the coal store should be "international," and retaining his rights of sovereignty over the island. Koomeh, a small islet a few miles from Farsan, was then selected by the Sultan as the site of the coal store, and some buildings were constructed by the Turkish authorities there, but, apparently, Germany was not satisfied with Koomeh, and hence har constant interest in Farsan.

It is difficult to advance any good reason for the German anxiety to establish themselves in the Red Sea. The Chinese crisis no longer exists and the necessity for a coal depot has disappeared. Parsan is the biggest and most important island in the Red Sea. It has salt and petroleum mines, and it is said that it also possesses a coal mine. Besides these mineral deposits, Farsan has a pearl-fishery in its waters, which is the most important pearlfishery in the Red Sea. Formerly it was garri. soned by a very small number of Turkish troops but since the Germans landed the coal, it has been garrisoned by a force of troops. Koomeh is a small islet and comparatively of little valge, and its capabilities as a naval base offer very little attraction.

div.head: The Mecca Mission.
div.p: The Commission from Mecca has arrived at Sana, in company with two Turkish Pashas. The programme of the Commission is still unsettled. They propose, if possible, I under. stand, to proceed from Sana to Al Kufią, which lies about three days' distance from Sana, where the Imam is now stopping, and then a conference will he held and negotiations will be conducted. If it is not possible for them to reach Al Kutla, they will stop at Sana and from there they will conduct the negotiations by letters.

div.head: THE CAIRO CONGRESS.
div.p: REFORM OF ISLAM

A few days ago we published a telegram announcing that the celebrated Oriental traveller Professor Vambery of Buda Pesth University, had suggested the holding of an Islamic Congress at Cairo. The following are his suggestions :-
In my correspondence with the civilized Mahomedans it has frequently struck me that the ideas, not only of social and cultural, but also of religious reform is steadily gaining

ground. In former times any approach to similar questions was reckoned amongst the post hazardous, nay, sacrilegious problems, and even the most courageous reformer would have shrunk from mentioning the words religions reform, by which he might have been accused of heresy and despised by his fellow-believers. Quite recently, however, a change is noticeable in this direction. Religious topics, thought to be the sacrosanct of Islam, are unsparingly discussed, and I have before me a Tartar paper called Terdjuman (i e., the "Interpreter"), and published in Bagchesarai in the Crimes, in which the proposition is made to discuss in a congress questions of general importance for Islam, with the exclusion of all political tendencies and bearings. The appeal is signed by its editor, Ismael Bey Gasprinski, and published in No. 60 of the said paper. It runs as follows :-

In paying due attention to the relations of the Mahomedan world, we shall be grieved to notice that, wherever and under whatever rule they be, they always remain behind their neighbours. In Algiers the Mabomedans are superseded by the Jews, in Crete by the Greeks, in Bulgaria by the Bulgarians, and in Russia by everybody. It is patent that, groaning under despotism and unable to profit by liberty and Constitution, they pass their time in patience and submission. We ought to investigate into the causes of this deplorable state, for admitting, for example, that the Algerian Jews surpass the Algerian Arab, it is astonishing and quite inexplicable that the poor and devont Buddhist should get ahead of the once energetic Moslem.

This is the much more to be wondered at when we see that in recent times important thoughts and questions have arisen in the Islam world, and that, amongst others, the situation of our women has been ander discussion in Egypt, Russia, and India. There have been besides many other topics touched relating to the mutual condition of the Eastern and Western civilization ; questions which ought to be handled with ripe consideration and solved in accordance with the special wants of the different countries. Bat since these questions are of extraordinary interest for the cultural revival of Islam, it is preferable to discuss these matters in a common general way, instead of the hitherto used single and separate form. The first congress of the Rossian Mohamedans in 1905 has greatly contributed towards the rousing and development of these thoughts, and now a much greater ne cessity has arisen for the convening of a general congress, the activity of which may be useful to Islam. The congress, embodying our learned clergy and literary celebrities, must not be frightened by the European clamour of Pan-Islamism, for our representatives, gathering from all parts of the world, and striving to solve many social and cultural questions, will open more than one hitherto barred way and door. We shall thus be able to sanction the unavoidably necessary reforms and innovations in Islam. After obtaining by deliberation the unity of thought, and by striving to propagate these ideas in the whole Islam world, we shall have created a sound understanding and a general awakening of the hitherto sleeping Mahomedans. At the time of pnblic association Islam was a rul. ing power, now three-fourths of it are ruled by others. The world is constantly changing and progressing, and we are left behind for many many miles. As this congress, owing to certain reasons, cannot meet in Constanti. nople, we trust to be able to unite in Cairo, which is looked upon as the second centre of Islam. We are anxious to have the opinion of the Mahomedan Press concerning the programme and the discussable points, and there is much hope that we shall meet in September next year in Cairo.-- ISMAEL.

I dare say nobody will undervalue the importance of this appeal. There are three points which deserve our particular attention. (1) Mahomedan reformers do not choose for their gathering the seat of the spiritual chief of Islam, bat a town, which they call the second centre of Islam-pamely, Cairo—where, sheltered by the British, they find full guarantee for free speech and an unrestrained discussion. This public acknowledgment of the toleration of British rule will afford a good leason to the clamouring Nationalists on the Nile, whether they take it to heart or not. (2) The appeal furnishes an open disavowal of any Pan-Islam tendency, which never could enter the mind of any sober-thinking Mahomodan under the present circumstances and which every Christian knowing the East must declare to be a bogey (3) It will ovidently striko one that, amongst all Mahomedans, it is just the Tartans who coine forward with the important proposal, which, owing to the immovability of the tenets of Islam, the moven of the congress will bave to treat with great caution and moderation Their object in view being decidedly the re formation of Islam, they are just now engaged in the preparatory labour, a fact which is fully deserving our attention.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture de terre noire (dite Cina), de pots à Henrs de différentes dimensions et de tuyaux en poterie Marseille et Baladi de différents diamètres
Le cautionnement est fixé à L. Eg. 20 (vingt).
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau les Parcs et Plantations on il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.

Les offres devront être adressées sons pli cacheté à Monsieur le Vice-Président de la Municipalité avant le 12 Novembre prochain. Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : "Soumission pour fourniture de Cina, pots à fleurs et tuyaux en poterie".
Le cautionnement prévu au cahier des charges devra être versé au service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 12 novembre de 9h. a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
Alexandrie, le 26 Octobre 1907.
Le Vice-Président,
(Signé) DR. SCHIESS.
